Award.AwardTitle: Many-Body Theory of Ultracold Atoms and Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research program explores the quantum physics of thin vapors of atoms and molecules at nanokelvin temperature scales controlled by laser beams, magnetic fields and electric fields. It seeks to uncover relationships between different, seemingly unrelated, physical properties of given many-body systems, to yield extremely precise knowledge about the interactions in certain systems that can flow without friction, to predict basic properties of vapors confined in a thin tube, to uncover new liquids and solids that are, counterintuitively, millions of times thinner than the air, to reveal properties of fast rotating strongly interacting quantum gases, and to understand the behavior of many atoms near narrow resonances. The project builds on the knowledge about one or a few atoms or molecules and extends to the collective behavior of a large number of them.

At least one graduate student will participate in the project by close interaction with the principal investigator (PI) and learn a wide range of techniques and concepts in theoretical condensed matter physics. The project is interdisciplinary, bringing ideas from solid state physics and nuclear physics to the research of matter at extremely low temperatures. Theoretical results out of this project will stimulate experimental work on verifying or realizing them around the world, and are likely to have a very positive impact on the development of technology. Traditionally physics is about the properties of things that exist in nature; with the technology to control atoms more and more states of matter will be created, and become a focus of research. Public awareness of this change will be increased by talks and lectures by the PI.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In many laboratories across the world, people are experimenting with thin vapors of atoms cooled to unthinkable temperatures like just 0.000000001 degree above absolute zero. Our common sense notion of atoms being like billiard balls bouncing around fail in these extreme cases. And it is wrong to say atoms behave as waves, like sound waves in the air. Instead, we must think of them as a single wave in a gigantic space having 3*N dimensions, where N is the number of atoms. This picture presents enormous challenge to our understanding of what were created in the laboratories. The challenge is so great that even the world's fastest supercomputers can not tackle the whole problem. This is known as the "quantum many-body problem".

So why do we still want to better understand the cold atoms? The reasons are roughly two-fold. Firstly, ALL microscopic particles, be they cold atoms, nuclear particles (as seen in nuclear facilities), or electrons (as seen in many useful materials) obey the same set of physical laws. Better understanding of one system can help us to better understand other systems, because of that similarity. Unlike nuclear particles or electrons, people can vary the behavior of extremely cold atoms with much greater ease. Since we can vary things at will, we have many chances to understand them better. Secondly, the extremely cold atoms have many technical applications. A prominent example is the world's most accurate clocks, which are based on extremely cold atoms at their heart. Without these clocks, common technologies such as the Global Positioning System would not work. Being extremely sensitive to tiny changes in their surroundings, these atoms will also have applications in precision navigation (eg, in missiles), gravity measurement (eg, in mining), etc.

This project builds upon the PI's prior record of theoretical study of cold atoms, for which he was awarded a Prize by the American Physical Society in 2010. The goal of the project was to understand the system of cold atoms from the angles of exact analytical methods and few-body theory. To draw an analogy with sociology, an understanding of the interactions between two or three people may help us to better understand a larger society; likewise, few-body theory provides some useful building blocks in our understanding of bigger systems having many more atoms.

The many-body problem is so hard that people often can not make reliable quantitative predictions of the physical properties of many strongly interacting extremely cold atoms, even though we are confident that we know the microscopic physical laws governing individual atoms. The PI has made quantitative predictions about the RELATIONS between various physical properties, even though none of them can be calculated using today's most powerful computers. One such relation involves the velocity distribution of atoms when people suddenly turn off both the forces between the atoms (approximately) and the laser forces that confine them in a vacuum chamber.

The PI predicted more precise ways to control the forces between certain cold atoms, such as potassium atoms, using a magnetic field. He and his collaborators showed how one could entangle pairs of atoms such that they could potentially be useful for technical applications like quantum computation.

The PI and his students studied certain universal behaviors of cold atoms, behaviors that do NOT depend on the specific details of the microscopic forces between the atoms. Such behaviors are common to atoms of different chemical elements, when they are controlled by laser light, magnetic field, and/or microwave field in certain ways in a vacuum chamber.
